author: Christopher Knaus
title: Mike Baird takes job with National Australia Bank a month after quitting politics | Australia news | The Guardian
text:
Mike Baird takes job with National Australia Bank a month after quitting politics 
Former Liberal premier will be chief customer officer for corporate and institutional banking at NAB National Australia Bank has appointed the former New South Wales premier Mike Baird as chief customer officer for corporate and institutional banking. Photograph: Dean Lewins/AAP View more sharing options Monday 27 February 2017 22.53 GMT Last modified on Monday 27 February 2017 22.57 GMT 
The former New South Wales premier Mike Baird has taken a job as a senior executive at the National Australia Bank a month after leaving politics. 
Baird will work as chief customer officer for corporate and institutional banking at NAB. He began his banking career as a graduate at NAB in 1989. 
NAB made the announcement on Tuesday morning , saying Baird would return to the bank with “invaluable experience”. 
“His time as treasurer and premier of New South Wales means he returns to banking and NAB with invaluable experience in leading economic and financial reform to grow the economy,” NAB’s chief executive, Andrew Thorburn, said. New South Wales premier Mike Baird announces retirement Read more 
“Mike has outstanding leadership and a determination to drive change and make a difference by building relationships with customers and the community.” 
Baird resigned from politics in mid-January, saying he wanted to spend more time with his family . He said he wanted more time with his wife and children, as well as his elderly parents and unwell sister. 
“My father has gone through open-heart surgery, he’s got a long road back to recovery,” Baird said. “He had become the primary carer for my mother, she’s just gone to 24 hours care, she’s got muscular dystrophy disorder, so basically she’s losing function in everything. That’s very tough to watch as a son. 
“My sister’s had a recurrence of cancer. I was in hospital with her last week. Those personal things obviously impact you. And the nature of this job makes it tough to be able to support as much as you want.” 
Baird follows a string of former state premiers who have worked in banking after politics. The former NSW premier Bob Carr joined Maquarie Bank in October 2005 as a part-time consultant only two months after he left state politics. 
The former Labor Queensland premier Anna Bligh was recently appointed chief executive of the Australian Bankers’ Association. Thorburn also made that appointment. 
Baird spent 17 years in banking in Australia, London and New Zealand. He also worked with Deutsche Bank and HSBC before entering politics. 
NAB said that Baird would start in mid-April, subject to regulatory approval.
